quiz.title: Chemistry Grade 11: Unit 4 Quiz 6
quiz.subtitle: 4.6: Bond Order and Magnetic Properties (MO Theory)
quiz.subject: Chemistry

questions.question: What is the mathematical formula for calculating Bond Order in Molecular Orbital Theory?
questions.explanation: Bond order is half the difference between the number of electrons in bonding orbitals and anti-bonding orbitals. It represents the net number of electron pairs holding the atoms together.

questions.question: Which of the following describes a 'paramagnetic' substance?
options: It contains unpaired electrons and is attracted to a magnetic field
It contains only paired electrons and is repelled by a magnetic field
It has a bond order of exactly zero
It can only exist in the presence of an electric current
questions.explanation: Paramagnetism occurs when unpaired electrons are present. The magnetic moments of these electrons align with an external field, creating an attraction.

questions.question: If a molecule has a bond order of 2.5, it is expected to be:
options: Stronger than a double bond but weaker than a triple bond
Exactly as strong as a triple bond
questions.explanation: Bond strength increases directly with bond order. A 2.5 bond order falls between a double (2) and triple (3) bond in terms of energy and length.

questions.question: Which relationship between bond order and bond length is correct?
options: As bond order increases, bond length decreases
As bond order increases, bond length increases
Bond order and bond length are not related
Bond length is always half of the bond order
questions.explanation: Higher bond orders mean more electron density between the nuclei, pulling them closer together and resulting in a shorter bond length.

questions.question: Which of the following species is diamagnetic?
questions.explanation: Nitrogen has 10 valence electrons, all of which are paired in bonding orbitals. While the peroxide ion is also diamagnetic, $N_2$ is the most common example in neutral diatomic molecules.

questions.question: What happens to the magnetic property of $O_2$ if it is ionized to $O_2^{2-}$?
options: It changes from paramagnetic to diamagnetic
It changes from diamagnetic to paramagnetic
questions.explanation: Oxygen ($O_2$) has two unpaired electrons in its $\pi^*$ orbitals. Adding two electrons to form $O_2^{2-}$ pairs them up, making the ion diamagnetic.

questions.question: Comparing $N_2$ and $N_2^+$, which statement is true?
options: $N_2$ has a shorter bond and is diamagnetic
$N_2^+$ has a shorter bond and is paramagnetic
They have the same bond length
questions.explanation: $N_2$ (bond order 3) is stronger/shorter than $N_2^+$ (bond order 2.5). $N_2$ has all paired electrons, while $N_2^+$ has one unpaired electron.

questions.question: A substance that is weakly repelled by a magnetic field is called:
questions.explanation: Diamagnetism is a property of all matter, but it is only observed when all electrons are paired. It results in a very weak repulsion from a magnetic field.

questions.question: How does removing an electron from an anti-bonding orbital affect the molecule?
options: The bond order increases and the molecule becomes more stable
The bond order decreases and the molecule becomes less stable
The bond order remains the same
The molecule immediately dissociates into atoms
questions.explanation: Because anti-bonding electrons work against the bond, removing them increases the net bond order and strengthens the molecule (e.g., $O_2$ to $O_2^+$).

questions.question: Which of the following has the highest bond dissociation energy?
questions.explanation: Bond dissociation energy is the energy required to break a bond. Nitrogen's triple bond is exceptionally strong due to its high bond order.

scoreMessages.90: Excellent! You can accurately predict the physical destiny of a molecule.
scoreMessages.70: Great job. You're connecting electron configurations to real-world properties.
scoreMessages.50: Good effort. Remember: Bonding electrons build the bond; anti-bonding electrons break it.
scoreMessages.0: Review the bond order formula and the definition of paramagnetism.
